t: For the choir director. A Maskil of the sons of Korah.
As*pn a deer longs for flowing streams, so*ln I long for you, God.
I*ln thirst for God, the living God. When*ln can I come and appear before God?
My*ln tears have been my food day and night, while*ln all day long people say to me, “Where*ln is your God?”
I*ln remember this as I pour out my heart: how*ln I walked with many, leading*ln the festive procession to the house of God, with*ln joyful and thankful shouts.
Why,*pn my soul, are you so dejected? Why*ln are you in such turmoil? Put*ln your hope in God, for I will still praise him, my*ln Savior and my God.
I*ln am deeply depressed; therefore*ln I remember you from the land of Jordan and*ln the peaks of Hermon, from Mount Mizar.
Deep*ln calls to deep in the roar of your waterfalls; all*ln your breakers and your billows have swept over me.
The*ln Lord*s will send his faithful love by day; his*ln song will be with me in the night — a*ln prayer to the God of my life.
I*pn will say to God, my rock, “Why*ln have you forgotten me? Why*ln must I go about in sorrow because*ln of the enemy’s oppression?”
My*ln adversaries taunt me, as*ln if crushing my bones, while*ln all day long they say to me, “Where*ln is your God?”
Why,*ln my soul, are you so dejected? Why*ln are you in such turmoil? Put*ln your hope in God, for I will still praise him, my*ln Savior and my God.
